segment.source: This section describes how to modify your PlayReady Web app to support the changes made from the previous Windows 8.1 version to the Windows 10 version.
segment.target: This section describes how to modify your PlayReady Web app to support the changes made from the previous Windows 8.1 version to the Windows 10 version.

segment.source: PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension
segment.target: PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension

segment.source: PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension
segment.target: PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This section describes how to modify your PlayReady Web app to support the changes made from the previous Windows 8.1 version to the Windows 10 version.
segment.target: This section describes how to modify your PlayReady Web app to support the changes made from the previous Windows 8.1 version to the Windows 10 version.

segment.source: Using PlayReady media elements in Internet Explorer enables developers to create Web apps capable of providing PlayReady content to the user while enforcing the access rules defined by the content provider.
segment.target: Using PlayReady media elements in Internet Explorer enables developers to create Web apps capable of providing PlayReady content to the user while enforcing the access rules defined by the content provider.

segment.source: This section describes how to add PlayReady media elements to your existing Web apps using only HTML5 and JavaScript.
segment.target: This section describes how to add PlayReady media elements to your existing Web apps using only HTML5 and JavaScript.

segment.source: What's New in PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension
segment.target: What's New in PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension

segment.source: This section provides a list of changes made to the PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension to enable PlayReady content protection on Windows 10.
segment.target: This section provides a list of changes made to the PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension to enable PlayReady content protection on Windows 10.

segment.source: The following list describes the new features and changes made to PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension for Windows 10:
segment.target: The following list describes the new features and changes made to PlayReady Encrypted Media Extension for Windows 10:

segment.source: Added hardware digital rights management (DRM).
segment.target: Added hardware digital rights management (DRM).

segment.source: Hardware-based content protection support enables secure playback of high definition (HD) and ultra-high definition (UHD) content on multiple device platforms.
segment.target: Hardware-based content protection support enables secure playback of high definition (HD) and ultra-high definition (UHD) content on multiple device platforms.

segment.source: Key material (including private keys, content keys, and any other key material used to derive or unlock said keys), and decrypted compressed and uncompressed video samples are protected by leveraging hardware security.
segment.target: Key material (including private keys, content keys, and any other key material used to derive or unlock said keys), and decrypted compressed and uncompressed video samples are protected by leveraging hardware security.

segment.source: Provides proactive acquisition of non-persistent licenses.
segment.target: Provides proactive acquisition of non-persistent licenses.

segment.source: Provides acquisition of multiple licenses in one message.
segment.target: Provides acquisition of multiple licenses in one message.

segment.source: You can either use a PlayReady object with multiple key identifiers (KeyIDs) as in Windows 8.1, or use content decryption model data (CDMData) with multiple KeyIDs.
segment.target: You can either use a PlayReady object with multiple key identifiers (KeyIDs) as in Windows 8.1, or use content decryption model data (CDMData) with multiple KeyIDs.

segment.source: Note In Windows 10, multiple key identifiers are supported under KeyID in CDMData.
segment.target: Note In Windows 10, multiple key identifiers are supported under KeyID in CDMData.

segment.source: Added real time expiration support, or limited duration license (LDL).
segment.target: Added real time expiration support, or limited duration license (LDL).

segment.source: Provides the ability to set real-time expiration on licenses.
segment.target: Provides the ability to set real-time expiration on licenses.

segment.source: Added HDCP Type 1 (version 2.2) policy support.
segment.target: Added HDCP Type 1 (version 2.2) policy support.

segment.source: Miracast is now implicit as an output.
segment.target: Miracast is now implicit as an output.

segment.source: Added secure stop.
segment.target: Added secure stop.

segment.source: Secure stop provides the means for a PlayReady device to confidently assert to a media streaming service that media playback has stopped for any given piece of content.
segment.target: Secure stop provides the means for a PlayReady device to confidently assert to a media streaming service that media playback has stopped for any given piece of content.

segment.source: Added audio and video license separation.
segment.target: Added audio and video license separation.

segment.source: Separate tracks prevent video from being decoded as audio; enabling more robust content protection.
segment.target: Separate tracks prevent video from being decoded as audio; enabling more robust content protection.

segment.source: Emerging standards are requiring separate keys for audio and visual tracks.
segment.target: Emerging standards are requiring separate keys for audio and visual tracks.

segment.source: Added MaxResDecode.
segment.target: Added MaxResDecode.

segment.source: This feature was added to limit playback of content to a maximum resolution even when in possession of a more capable key (but not a license).
segment.target: This feature was added to limit playback of content to a maximum resolution even when in possession of a more capable key (but not a license).

segment.source: It supports cases where multiple stream sizes are encoded with a single key.
segment.target: It supports cases where multiple stream sizes are encoded with a single key.

segment.source: Encrypted Media Extension Support in PlayReady
segment.target: Encrypted Media Extension Support in PlayReady

segment.source: This section describes the version of the W3C Encrypted Media Extension supported by PlayReady.
segment.target: This section describes the version of the W3C Encrypted Media Extension supported by PlayReady.

segment.source: PlayReady for Web Apps is currently bound to the W3C Encrypted Media Extension (EME) draft of May 10, 2013.
segment.target: PlayReady for Web Apps is currently bound to the W3C Encrypted Media Extension (EME) draft of May 10, 2013.

segment.source: This support will be changed to the updated EME specification in future versions of Windows.
segment.target: This support will be changed to the updated EME specification in future versions of Windows.

segment.source: Use Hardware DRM
segment.target: Use Hardware DRM

segment.source: This section describes how your web app can use PlayReady hardware DRM, and how to disable hardware DRM if the protected content does not support it.
segment.target: This section describes how your web app can use PlayReady hardware DRM, and how to disable hardware DRM if the protected content does not support it.

segment.source: To use PlayReady hardware DRM, your JavaScript web app should use the isTypeSupported EME method with a key system identifier of to query for PlayReady hardware DRM support from the browser.
segment.target: To use PlayReady hardware DRM, your JavaScript web app should use the isTypeSupported EME method with a key system identifier of to query for PlayReady hardware DRM support from the browser.

segment.source: Occasionally, some content is not supported in hardware DRM.
segment.target: Occasionally, some content is not supported in hardware DRM.

segment.source: Cocktail content is never supported in hardware DRM; if you want to play cocktail content, you must opt out of hardware DRM.
segment.target: Cocktail content is never supported in hardware DRM; if you want to play cocktail content, you must opt out of hardware DRM.

segment.source: Some hardware DRM will support HEVC and some will not; if you want to play HEVC content and hardware DRM doesn’t support it, you will want to opt out as well.
segment.target: Some hardware DRM will support HEVC and some will not; if you want to play HEVC content and hardware DRM doesn’t support it, you will want to opt out as well.

segment.source: Note To determine whether HEVC content is supported, after instantiating , use the PlayReadyStatics.CheckSupportedHardware method.
segment.target: Note To determine whether HEVC content is supported, after instantiating , use the PlayReadyStatics.CheckSupportedHardware method.

segment.source: Add Secure Stop to your Web App
segment.target: Add Secure Stop to your Web App

segment.source: This section describes how to add secure stop to your web app.
segment.target: This section describes how to add secure stop to your web app.

segment.source: Secure stop provides the means for a PlayReady device to confidently assert to a media streaming service that media playback has stopped for any given piece of content.
segment.target: Secure stop provides the means for a PlayReady device to confidently assert to a media streaming service that media playback has stopped for any given piece of content.

segment.source: This capability ensures your media streaming services provide accurate enforcement and reporting of usage limitations on different devices for a given account.
segment.target: This capability ensures your media streaming services provide accurate enforcement and reporting of usage limitations on different devices for a given account.

segment.source: There are two primary scenarios for sending a secure stop challenge:
segment.target: There are two primary scenarios for sending a secure stop challenge:

segment.source: When the media presentation stops because end of content was reached or when the user stopped the media presentation somewhere in the middle.
segment.target: When the media presentation stops because end of content was reached or when the user stopped the media presentation somewhere in the middle.

segment.source: When the previous session ends unexpectedly (for example, due to a system or app crash).
segment.target: When the previous session ends unexpectedly (for example, due to a system or app crash).

segment.source: The app will need to query, either at startup or shutdown, for any outstanding secure stop sessions and send challenge(s) separate from any other media playback.
segment.target: The app will need to query, either at startup or shutdown, for any outstanding secure stop sessions and send challenge(s) separate from any other media playback.

segment.source: The following procedures describe how to set up secure stop for various scenarios.
segment.target: The following procedures describe how to set up secure stop for various scenarios.

segment.source: To set up secure stop for a normal end of a presentation:
segment.target: To set up secure stop for a normal end of a presentation:

segment.source: Register the onEnded event before playback starts.
segment.target: Register the onEnded event before playback starts.

segment.source: The onEnded event handler needs to call from the video/audio element object to set the source to NULL which will trigger the media foundation to tear down the topology, destroy the decryptor(s), and set the stop state.
segment.target: The onEnded event handler needs to call from the video/audio element object to set the source to NULL which will trigger the media foundation to tear down the topology, destroy the decryptor(s), and set the stop state.

segment.source: You can start the secure stop CDM session inside the handler to send the secure stop challenge to the server to notify the playback has stopped at this time, but it can be done later as well.
segment.target: You can start the secure stop CDM session inside the handler to send the secure stop challenge to the server to notify the playback has stopped at this time, but it can be done later as well.

segment.source: To set up secure stop if the user navigates away from the page or closes down the tab or browser:
segment.target: To set up secure stop if the user navigates away from the page or closes down the tab or browser:

segment.source: No app action is required to record the stop state; it will be recorded for you.
segment.target: No app action is required to record the stop state; it will be recorded for you.

segment.source: To set up secure stop for custom page controls or user actions (such as custom navigation buttons or starting a new presentation before the current presentation completed):
segment.target: To set up secure stop for custom page controls or user actions (such as custom navigation buttons or starting a new presentation before the current presentation completed):

segment.source: When custom user action occurs, the app needs to set the source to NULL which will trigger the media foundation to tear down the topology, destroy the decryptor(s), and set the stop state.
segment.target: When custom user action occurs, the app needs to set the source to NULL which will trigger the media foundation to tear down the topology, destroy the decryptor(s), and set the stop state.

segment.source: The following example demonstrates how to use secure stop in your web app:
segment.target: The following example demonstrates how to use secure stop in your web app:

segment.source: Note The secure stop data’s in the sample above can be an asterisk (\*), which is a wild card for all the secure stop sessions recorded.
segment.target: Note The secure stop data’s in the sample above can be an asterisk (\*), which is a wild card for all the secure stop sessions recorded.

segment.source: That is, the SessionID tag can be a specific session, or a wild card (\*) to select all the secure stop sessions.
segment.target: That is, the SessionID tag can be a specific session, or a wild card (\*) to select all the secure stop sessions.

segment.source: Programming Considerations for Encrypted Media Extension
segment.target: Programming Considerations for Encrypted Media Extension

segment.source: This section lists the programming considerations that you should take into account when creating your PlayReady-enabled web app for Windows 10.
segment.target: This section lists the programming considerations that you should take into account when creating your PlayReady-enabled web app for Windows 10.

segment.source: The MSMediaKeys and MSMediaKeySession objects created by your app must be kept alive until your app closes.
segment.target: The MSMediaKeys and MSMediaKeySession objects created by your app must be kept alive until your app closes.

segment.source: One way of ensuring these objects stay alive is to assign them as global variables (the variables would become out of scope and subject to garbage collection if declared as a local variable inside of a function).
segment.target: One way of ensuring these objects stay alive is to assign them as global variables (the variables would become out of scope and subject to garbage collection if declared as a local variable inside of a function).

segment.source: For example, the following sample assigns the variables g\_msMediaKeys and g\_mediaKeySession as global variables, which are then assigned to the MSMediaKeys and MSMediaKeySession objects in the function.
segment.target: For example, the following sample assigns the variables g\_msMediaKeys and g\_mediaKeySession as global variables, which are then assigned to the MSMediaKeys and MSMediaKeySession objects in the function.

segment.source: Refer to the sample applications for more information.
segment.target: Refer to the sample applications for more information.
